TopicTitle: Help me design a boatcar to go around Kerbin

Articles.Content:
I've been inspired by that Circumnavigating the Klobe Challenge thread. I'm not very good at KSP so for me the challenge is making a car to do it at all, I'm not worried about being fast! My current rough draft build is this thing:

The problem is it can only manage 15m/s on water, giving it a water range of about 120km. Using the map on Kerbal Wiki, which indicates 1 degree = 10.5km, I need to drive on water for about 250km so I'd like 300km water range ideally. I'd much prefer to 2.5x my speed rather than 2.5x my amount of fuel! So...

1) What is slowing me down in the water?
2) should I ditch the rover wheels, using jet power only and enter the world of mining (or maybe put a docking port on it and drop in fuel supplies by air- it would be fun to design a support plane)

6 minutes ago, Stewcumber said:

1) What is slowing me down in the water?
2) should I ditch the rover wheels, using jet power only and enter the world of mining (or maybe put a docking port on it and drop in fuel supplies by air- it would be fun to design a support plane)

1.  Drag.  All those box girders and wheels.  If you want high water speed, you need a smooth hull.

2.  Rover wheels aren't very strong and have low max speed.  If you want to go fast on land, use the small gear bay, which can be steered and is very strong and fast.  Plus, it retracts so causes way less water drag.

As to what you should do, that depends on how you want to go around Kerbin.  The choices are mostly on land or mostly on water.  It's impossible to go around Kerbin completely on land or water.  Either way, you need to optimize your vehicle for its main environment,  Without mods, airplane wheels are still usually the best bet either way due to their ability to go fast on land and retract in the water.  But this means you can't use electric power on land so need fuel, and thus refueling.  There are several options with refueling, ranging from carrying drilling/refining equipment with you to prepositioning fuel tanks along the route.  In the latter case, just have a Klaw on the vehicle to dock with the tanks.

If you go with mods, then there are many other possibilities.  For instance, Firespitter.  This has pontoons with retractable, powered rover wheels.  You can thus zip along in the water and drive up on the beach to cross small land obstacles.  And it also has electric props so you can move on both land and water without needing fuel.  That's what I used to boat around Kerbin.

Keep in mind that 1.0.5 water is a relatively new phenomena, and there aren't many experts on it. Neither am I, so take any advice with a grain of salt.

27 minutes ago, Stewcumber said:

1) What is slowing me down in the water?

Well, mass. Or to be precise, stuff pushed underwater by the mass above it. I'd start by throwing everything away that isn't strictly needed. If I'm right and this is a sandbox-save, I'd start with all those batteries and solar panels and use RTGs instead. Do the wheels need all those structural girders to touch the ground? Can't you just lower them with the offset tool?

An idea to gain more water speed: Add some down facing juno engines on the skids. Maybe just two on the front, maybe four on both ends. Make sure to set the throttle limit to a low value, as you don't want to fly or use too much fuel. (the engines won't connect radially to the fuselages, but you can add a small cubic strut, and clip it inside) I used it to push my SSTO underwater, but it can work backwards too. Upwards I mean.

 

27 minutes ago, Stewcumber said:

2) should I ditch the rover wheels, using jet power only and enter the world of mining (or maybe put a docking port on it and drop in fuel supplies by air- it would be fun to design a support plane)

I don't really see how could you move on the soil without wheels, but 100 funds says you won't be able to do a ground-based circumnavigation without any kind of supply drop anyways. It's not unlikely that you'll even need a whole replacement vehicle. But if you are already thinking in flying support to the craft, you might as well calculate refueling in. Extra points for doing it on water. Hint: docking with ports on the surface is a really painful process, a klaw is much easier.

I ditched the rover wheels (and girder support) and now I can do 45m/s in the water. It's looking like a jet powered run and I need to get to grips with the Klaw.

When I try to 'drive' up a steep incline, my jet flames out... how come?

Keep in mind, that it's enough if only the refueling vehicles (or pods) are klawed.

About jets flaming out... I'm absolutely clueless. Unless something like intakes break. Generally planes do more manuvering than following the shape of the ground, so the engines are designed to function in every angle.

Pay attention to the intake "effective base speed" stat in the SPH.  The hypersonic and structural intakes are poor at low/zero speed and might not supply enough intake air to go full throttle?  Look at the nacelle and precooler.

By the way: in the new 1.0.5 water, hydrofoils work. So you can design a craft with some fins below the waterline, and rely on hydrofoil lift rather than buoyancy to stay afloat. Helps to minimize submerged area, so you can go faster on the water with less thrust.

In the end I went for this design, Bluebird, based on your advice- thanks guys! Especially proud of Jeb and Co's gangway out of the cockpit!

On the flat I coasted up to 60m/s at about a quater power burning 0.07u/s. With my 3200 units of fuel that's 2,742km. If more typically I achieve 20m/s at 1/4 power that's 914km before I need to get my refuelling plane over there. On the water it can manage 40m/s at 0.21u/s or so (whatever the Wheezly flat out uses). Bonus 'press' action shot:

I didn't go with hydrofoils as they would (and did ) get pulled off if/when the car rolled from side to side.

Nice-looking ride!  Part of its looks are the high-speed intakes but as others mentioned, you're going low and slow so perhaps the circular ones would do you better?

As to refueling via the Klaw, the important thing is to be controlling the part with the Klaw on it when you dock, don't drive something into a Klaw on another vehicle.  That used to make all sorts of Kraken weirdness.  Squad says they fixed a lot of Klaw issues in 1.0.5 but I still don't trust the thing for this.
